title: Pytorch Notes

content:
1. Basic Knowledge #Installation #Reference
OS Basic Knowledge #I previously studied courses on CSKaoyan, but other tutorials are also available.
Remote Link to Linux #Just need to install a FinalShell SSH Tool to complete remote link. (Installation Tutorial)
WSL #As an auxiliary tool for Linux, WSL is very convenient in some situations.
Snapshot #A snapshot is used to save the current state of your virtual machine as a backup.
Directory Structure #Linux has a file directory structure as shown in the following figure. The highest level directory is “/”. System defaults to the “home/” directory.
User & User Groups #Details
Shortcut Keys #ctrl+d: log out ctrl+c: stop history: show historical commands !: command prefix, match the previous command ctrl+r: search the history commands ctrl+l: clear screenDNS Resolution & Fixed IP Config #Details
Environment Variable Config #Details ($ means get value of a variable)
Compression and Decompression #Linux has two common compressed file format, which is “.tar” and “.gz”. The compression and depression methods of them is here.
2. Orders and Functions #Linux orders often looks like:
command [-options] [parameter] ls #ls [-a -l -h] [path] -a: show all (including hidden) files and folders -h: make information easier to read (often used together with “-l”) -l: list detailed information about files and foldersls -alh /	# show detailed information neatly of all files and folders in root directory cd & pwd & mkdir #cd: enter to path directory pwd: show current work path mkdir: create a new foldercd bob pwd mkdir [bob/]new_folder touch & cat & more #touch: create a new file cat: show the content of a file more: see the content of a file and support page turningtouch [bob/]test.txt cat [bob/]test.txt more [bob/]test.txt cp & rm & mv #cp [-r] old_file new_file	# Choose -r when copying a folder rm [-r -f] file1 file2...	# -f means force delete, -r means deleting folders mv old_path new_path cp: copy a file or folder mv: move a file or folder to a new path rm: delete files or folders (use a wildcard “*” to achieve fuzzy matching)rm -f *.txt	# Delete all files ending in ".txt" which & find #which order_name find begin_path -name "file_name" find begin_path -size +|-n[kMG]	# "+" means larger, "-" means smaller, k/M/G are size units which: find the path of order files find: find files or directories location, can be used together with wildcard “*”find / -name test*	# find paths of all files and directories starting in "test" since the root directory find / -size - 100M	# find paths of all files and directories smaller than 100M since the root directory grep & wc #grep [-n] keyword file_path	# choose "-n" when you want to see the the line number in the file where the keyword is located wc [-c -m -l -w] file_path grep: find the keyword location in the file, can be used in conjunction with other commands, connected by pipeline symbols “|” in between wc: count the number of lines, words, etc. in the file -c: count number of bytes -m: count number of characters -l: count number of lines -w: count number of wordscat test.txt | grep itheima | grep itcast	# find sentences containing "itheima" or "itcast" in test.txt wc -c test.txt echo & tail #echo content tail [-f -num] path	# choose "-f" when consistently follow a file, choose "-num" to point the number of last lines you want to see in the files (default with 10 lines) echo: print content instantly (suggest enclosing the output content with double quotation marks), can be used together with “>” or “>>” to write the output content to the file on the right. It can also be used with “`” to show the result of a command. >: overwrite >>: add write tail: show the last lines in a fileecho `pwd` >> test.txt	# append the result of the "pwd" command to the test.txt tail -f -20 test.txt	# continuously check the last 20 lines content of test.txt vi / vim #vim is an upgraded version of vi, which fully includes all the command methods of vi. In command mode: i: enter input mode at the cursor position a: enter input mode after the cursor position I: enter input mode at beginning of the line that the cursor position A: enter input mode at the end of the line that the cursor position o: enter input mode at the next line of cursor position O: enter input mode at the above line of cursor position esc: back to command mode in any situation [n]dd: delete n lines from cursor position [n]yy: copy the n+1 lines from current line p: paste u: revoke ctrl+r: reverse revoke gg: cursor jump to the first line G: cursor jump to the end of current line dG: delete all from the current line dgg: delete all above from the current line d$: delete content till the end of current line d0: delete content till the head of current line
In baseline command mode: :wq: save and quit :q: quit without save :q!: forced quit :w: save :set nu: show the number of current line :set paste: set the paste mode
su & sudo #su - [username]	# default as root sudo command su: switch to a user sudo: temporarily execute command instructions as root userchmod & chown #chmod [-R] authority path	# choose "-R" to authorize all files in the directory chown [-R] [user][:][group] [path] chmod: authorize files or folders, authority can be: r: read w: write x: executable chown: modify the user or user group to which a file or folder belongschmod u=rwx,g=rx,o=x hello.txt	# "u" means current user, "g" means group, "o" means other users sudo chown root test.txt	# when "root" used to be or will be the user of the file, command need to be carried under root or sudo yum & apt #yum [-y] [install | remove | search] software_name	# choose "-y" to automatically confirm apt [-y] [install | remove | search] software_name yum: install or remove or search softwares or commands for CentOS (need root authority and network) apt: “apt” has the same function with “yum”, while it is for Ubuntu systemsystemctl #systemctl start | stop | status | enable | disable service_name systemctl: view or operate system status, “service_name” can be: NetworkManager: main network service network: deputy network service firewalld: firewall service sshd: ssh serviceln #ln -s parameter1 parameter2	# parameter1: original file, parameter2: link destination ln: create a link, “-s” means soft linkifconfig & hostname & hostnamectl #ifconfig hostname hostnamectl set-hostname centos	# set the hostname as centos ifconfig: show the IP address of the host hostname: show host name hostnamectl: config host name (need root authority)ping & wget & curl #ping [-c num] ip_or_hostname	# "-c" means check times, default countless times wget [-b] url	# choose "-b" to download in background curl [-O] url	# choose "-O" when downloading ping: network check wget: download files curl: launch a network request (also can download files when choosing “-O”)nmap & netstat #nmap IP_address netstat -anp | grep port_number nmap: check the usage status of the host port corresponding to the IP address netstat: view a port usage statusps & kill #ps [-e -f]	# choose "-e" to see all process, choose "-f" to see all information kill [-9] PID	# "-9" means forced kill ps: see the process information in Linux, can be used together with “grep” kill: kill processps -ef | grep tail	# find all information of all process about "tail" top & df & iostat & sar #top [-p -d -c -n -b -i -u] parameter df [-h]	# choose "-h" to display more humanely iostat [-x] [num1] [num2]	# choose "-x" to show more information, "num1" means fresh interval, "num2" means fresh times sar -n DEV num1 num2	# "-n" means check network, "DEV" means view network interface, "num1" and "num2" has the same meaning above top: monitor system resources -p: only show a process information -d: set fresh time, default as 5 seconds -c: set the whole command that created the process -n: point the fresh times -b: execute “top” in batches, often be used together with “-n” and “>" -i: do not display any useless or idle processes -u: search for processes initiated by a specific user df: view disk usage iostat: view cpu and disk information sar: view network statusrz & sz #rz sz file_name rz: upload files to virtual machine sz: download files from virtual machine3. MySQL Project #
summary: By following Itheima, I’m learning some knowledge and basic orders about Linux. This article is only used for me to recall knowledge. If there are something hard to understand, please forgive me.
title: Linux

content:
I’m an Mphil student in HKUST(GZ) now, majoring in Artificial Intelligence. Prior to this, I pursued a Bachelor’s degree in Agriculture at Zhejiang University.
I have worked on some projects related to agricultural robots and insect image recognition during my undergraduate studies, which sparked my interest in artificial intelligence. As I switched to a new profession, I am still a novice🤡 in coding and professional skills.
I will periodically update my life🏃‍♂️, study📖, and research🖥️ related in this blog. You can point my fault if you want and have a pleasant discussion.👋🤣
